title: How long should a thesis topic be? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although most works are one or two (or maybe three) lines long on paper (in CS/CE), the true answer is “as long as needed to give a picture of your work”. Shorter but impactful names can make your work memorable. For example, “Candy Crush is NP-Hard.” We can discern IMMEDIATELY what happens in this work, without going overboard on the length. You could call it “Analysis of algorithmic complexity in video game Candy Crush” but it’s too long and full of fluff. It might suit the “gowns and robes” people more, but for us “sweaters and T-shirts” folks, the simple four-word sentence is enough to deliver the meaning we need. Now, this is my dissertation:  When deciding what to use, I first came up with three candidates, then discuss with the professors which would best describe my work. It wasn’t good enough and still needed a lot of polish. We spent a few hours back and forth discussing my work again and again to ensure that every single word is necessary to describe my work, and no more words are needed to describe my work as well. The best tip I can give you is that you should talk to your advisor about this, and present a few candidates. Remember to present candidate topics, because this is your work. You are the only one person in the world who fully understands your work. Your advisor is merely there to guide you. It’s your work. You know best. Use as many words as you need, but no more than that.
